prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Claims for Breach of Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: Fraud may be claimed where the wronged party consented to the disclosure of confidential information, but the consent was obtained by deceit or false representation. Section 380(1) of the Criminal Code[1] provides that, in order to succeed in a criminal action for fraud, the Crown must establish that one party was deprived by another of property or other valuables by means of deceit, false representation or other dishonest means. In the case of R. v. Kirkwood,[2] the accused copied tapes belonging to another and sold those tapes without notifying the holder of the copyright or distribution rights. The court held that, although the actual physical tapes had not been taken from the rightful owner, the accused had deprived the owner of the right to earn a profit from the rental or sale of these videotapes and, as such, the Crown had satisfied the onus of proving detriment, prejudice or risk of prejudice to the economic interests of the victim. The court further held that the rightful owners' interest was established, not by way of a property interest in the tapes themselves, but in the wronged party's right to profit from use of the tapes.
